question: Which of the following neurological diseases has the highest mortality rate?
What basal exudate will be seen in tuberculous meningitis?
What is the antidote to benzodiazepine poisoning?
Which of the following disorders is characterized by weakness in lower limbs and tongue, and dysphagia?
Which of the following neoplasms is characterized by a whorled cluster of cells without an obvious cell membrane?
Which of the following is not a sign of motor neuron disease?
Which of the following inhaled anesthetics is the least hepatotoxic?

A 60-year-old male with a past medical history of schizophrenia controlled by antipsychotics presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever, sweating, shortness of breath, and muscle stiffness. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a risk factor for subdural hematoma?
Which cranial nerve is an extension of the brain tract?
According to the International Classification of Diseases 10th Revision (ICD-10) classification, which of the following is the most typical complaint seen in depression?

answers.option: Loss of interest or pleasure in activities

question: Which cells are responsible for the myelination of central nervous system (CNS) axons?

A 36-year-old man with no relevant medical history presents to the emergency department with complaints of abnormal tongue motility, which causes difficulty in chewing food. The neurological examination reveals right-sided deviation of the tongue; the patient has difficulty moving it further to the right. Which cranial nerve is most likely damaged in this patient?

A 31-year-old female presents to the emergency room with a headache, fever, and swelling around the eyes. She has had a history of sinusitis for the past 4 months. Examination revealed decreased visual acuity, diminished pupillary reflexes, ptosis, periorbital edema, and painful eye movement. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema. Vitals include a temperature of 102°F, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 130/87 mmHg. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department (OPD) by his mother. She reports that her son hears voices that are not real, and faces problems making and keeping friends over the past 6 months. She also mentions how he has been feeling low, stopped taking an interest in his hobbies, and generally lazes about stating he no longer has the energy to carry out simple tasks. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the hospital with a severe headache and high-grade fever. Examination reveals he is irritable, febrile, and nuchal rigidity is present. A lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid detailed report (CSF D/R) is ordered. What finding would indicate viral meningitis?
Which of these is the first-line investigation in a patient presenting with subarachnoid hemorrhage?
A crescent-shaped lesion on computed tomography (CT) is a hallmark of which type of hemorrhage?

A 38-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of double vision and unable to open the right eye completely. She has a history of a road traffic accident 4 months back. On examination of the right eye, there is eyelid drooping. The eye deviates outward and downward. Which cranial nerve is most likely damaged in this patient?
A lesion in the medial lemniscus would result in which of the following?

answers.option: Contralateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception
Ipsilateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception
Ipsilateral loss of light touch and pressure
Contralateral loss of pain and temperature

question: An 8-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents with the complaint of inattention and inability to sit in the class. What is the probable diagnosis?
Which of the following disorder is not a risk factor for suicide?

A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with vision loss. He is unable to see anything in his temporal field of vision from both eyes. A lesion of the visual pathway is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of headache and papilledema. The magnetic resonance imaging of the head reveals a mass in the fourth ventricle. Which of the following neoplasms does he most likely have?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient department by her mother because she is unable to lift her arms to comb her hair. Laboratory analysis shows the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and serum creatinine kinase (CK) levels are raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 40-year-old woman undergoes a parotidectomy and the facial nerve is damaged during the procedure. Examination findings in this patient would most likely be summarized as which of the following?

answers.option: No facial weakness but ptosis is present
Weakness of the ipsilateral face movements with preservation of eye closing
Complete facial weakness on the ipsilateral side
Weakness of the contralateral face with the presence of forehead movement

question: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room after head trauma with complaints of headache and bleeding from the right ear. CT scan shows a right temporal bone fracture. He is discharged after a period of observation. One week later he came with difficulty in closing the right eye, which of the following nerve is likely to be involved in this case?
Which of the following is the most appropriate first step in the immediate management of a patient presenting to the emergency room with status epilepticus?

answers.option: Draw blood to send for complete blood count

question: Which of the following bacteria is a known cause of meningitis and can be diagnosed by Quellung reaction?

Which of the following anxiety disorders comprises of specific conditions?
What type of speech is observed in patients with mania?
Which of the following is caused by intoxication with lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD)?
Which cranial nerve carries sensory information in the corneal reflex?

A 43-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of fever, worsening headache, and neck stiffness for 4 days. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) detailed report shows neutrophilia, raised protein, and low glucose levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is a major risk factor for most forms of dementia?
Which enzyme produces amyloid beta-peptide (Aβ) through the proteolytic processing of the transmembrane glycoprotein?
What is the mechanism of action of tolcapone?

A 30-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of loss of pain and temperature sensations in the right arm. He has a history of gunshot wounds to the left side of the spinal cord. Where is the lesion located?

A 49-year-old man presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of the drooping left eyelid. On examination, the eyeball deviates downward laterally, and the pupil is dilated and unresponsive to light. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome?

A 50-year-old man presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with the complaint of a severe headache on the side of his head for the past 6 months. He also complains of vision loss in his left eye, blackouts, low-grade fever, and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 15-year-old male presents with the complaint of muscle twitching in arms and legs on waking up for the past 2-3 months. Which of the following would be your first differential diagnosis?

A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with weakness in both lower limbs. His upper limb function is normal and abdominal reflexes are absent. Which part of the spine should be assessed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)?

A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with symptoms of excessive cholinergic activity. He is a diagnosed case of myasthenia gravis for which he is taking pyridostigmine. Which of the following will confirm a cholinergic crisis?
Which nerve root allows elbow extension?
Which one of the following sensorimotor modalities is preserved in facial nerve lesions?

answers.option: Taste from hard and soft palates

question: Neural tube defects are due to a defect in which stage?
Which of the following is used for the treatment of inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy?
What is the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines?

answers.option: Blocks T-Type Ca 2+ channels in thalamic neurons
Facilitates GABA-A action by increasing frequency of Cl- channel opening

question: A 3-year-old boy with a reported intelligence quotient (IQ) of 45 is brought to the clinic. His parents complain that he is unable to communicate with them. What is his degree of intellectual disability?
Why is epinephrine recommended in local anesthesia?

A 37-year-old male presents to the neurology outpatient department with drooping eyelids and double vision. He is diagnosed with oculomotor nerve palsy. Damage to which vessel is most likely to cause his condition?
What is the global burden of neuropsychiatric disorders?
What is the standard intravenous dose of recombinant plasminogen tissue activator in ischemic stroke patients?
Which of these is not a common cause of non-compressive myelopathy?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a fever and an altered level of consciousness. He also has a low score on the Glasgow coma scale and complains of neck rigidity. What investigations should be performed?

answers.option: Lumbar puncture followed by computed tomography
Lumbar puncture followed by magnetic resonance imaging
Magnetic resonance imaging followed by a lumbar puncture
Computed tomography followed by lumbar puncture

question: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with an altered level of consciousness, and fever. His brother reports he has had a fever and neck stiffness for 2 days along with a rash on his arms and legs. What is the most probable diagnosis?
A patient starts using a drug that is prescribed to him and develops Parkinson-like features. Which drug is he most probably using?
Which drug is used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome?
Which of these best defines hyperactivity?

A 6-year-old male child weighing 20 kgs is brought to emergency with a history of weakness in both lower extremities, which has now progressively involved the trunk and upper limbs over a period of ten days. On examination, the sensations are intact, the tone is reduced, and reflexes are not elicited in lower limbs and +1 in upper limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which spinal ligament connects two laminae and fuses with the facet joint?

A 55-year-old male patient, previously diagnosed patient of diabetes mellitus type-2 and hypertension, is diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson disease. Which of the following symptoms is not typically seen in this condition?

A 29-year-old woman, 28 weeks pregnant, presents to the emergency room with persistent vomiting associated with mild to moderate diffuse headache and visual blurring for the last 2-3 weeks. Her last two pregnancies were uneventful. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg with a pulse of 102 beats/min and she is afebrile. The only significant finding on a neurologic exam is significant bilateral papilledema. Routine investigations show mild leukocytosis and sodium levels of 128 mEq/l. CSF analysis is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain is unremarkable, but MR venography showed filling defects in superior sagittal and bilateral transverse venous sinuses. APLA and the rest of the investigations for the autoimmune disease were negative. What could be the most likely predisposing etiological factor in her problem in this clinical vignette?

A 30-year-old male with a history of road traffic accident complains of severe backache and severe pain in both legs with paraparesis, urinary and fecal incontinence. A lesion of conus medullaris is suspected. Where does it terminate in adults?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months along with numbness in hands and feet. On examination, she has a bilateral high stepping gait with a positive Romberg sign. There was wasting and weakness of distal muscles of both upper and lower limbs with reduced reflexes. What will be the first investigation of choice to diagnose the disease?
What type of schizophrenia shows spasticity?
Which of the following causes schizophrenia?
Which of the following is a true statement about neurotransmitters?

answers.option: Adenosine receptors are blocked by caffeine
Acetylcholine is involved in motor and sensory system

answers.option: Altered mental status and cardiovascular instability
Respiratory depression with altered mental status

question: A woman is suspected to have a lumbar disc herniation. Why is magnetic resonance imagining recommended over computed tomography scan?

answers.option: It gives better view of bone
It gives better soft tissue visualization

answers.option: Keep patient lying in prone position

question: What is the most common cause of stroke?
A 40-year-old patient with Huntington's disease comes to a psychiatrist for the treatment of his psychosis. What drug will be prescribed to treat his mental condition?
Why is computed tomography opted for instead of magnetic resonance imaging for the imagining of brain lesions?

answers.option: More suitable for highly unstable patient

question: Which of these is clasically seen in anxiety disorders?
If a person survives after a suicide attempt, what is it called?

According to the McDonald criteria for the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, if a patient has 2 episodes separated in time and space, with clinical evidence of at least 2 lesions on MRI, what further investigations are required for the diagnosis of MS?

answers.option: Wait for another episode as further imaging needed
No further requirement as clinical evidence alone suffices
Wait for seeing a rise in intracranial pressure to perform lumbar puncture
Wait for another lesion with additional attacks
Wait 1 year to assess disease progression
